content: >http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/619749 The repatriation of the body of one of Canada's recent fallen in Afghanistan, has drawn criticism from some of the troops on board the aircraft with her. 21 year old Katrine Blais had to wait on the aircraft for three hours in Ottawa before being transported alone to Trenton for a ceremony. It was decided that it was necessary to drop returning troops near their home base, before bringing the body to her waiting family. The CinC has offered an apology to anyone offended by the decision.
reply: >http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/619749 The repatriation of the body of one of Canada's recent fallen in Afghanistan, has drawn criticism from some of the troops on board the aircraft with her. 21 year old Katrine Blais had to wait on the aircraft for three hours in Ottawa before being transported alone to Trenton for a ceremony. It was decided that it was necessary to drop returning troops near their home base, before bringing the body to her waiting family. The CinC has offered an apology to anyone offended by the decision.
title: Canadian Casualty Repatriation Draws Fire

content: Bless trooper Katrine. I don't know if the family felt shunned or not. But the Defense Chief issued a strong apology. An honor guard and friends showing support would have meant so much, though nothing will fill that empty spot in each of the family.

title: Canadian Casualty Repatriation Draws Fire
